feed.title: Combined summary - A BIP proposal for transactions that are 'cancellable'

entry.title: Combined summary - A BIP proposal for transactions that are 'cancellable'
entry.summary: A proposal has been made to extend OP_CSV and/or OP_CLTV in order to allow and interpret negative values to increase user fairness, but concerns have been raised about enforcing restrictions on the use of transactions after a specific time limit. An alternative approach involving multisig with a locktime pre-signed transaction has been suggested by Matt Corallo. Discussions are ongoing, and a BIP is being prepared.The proposed functionality of allowing time-based invalidation of transactions does not currently exist in the Bitcoin system due to potential negative effects. Nonetheless, a proposal to extend OP_CSV and/or OP_CLTV to allow and interpret negative values has been put forward. The authors have prepared a text for the BIP and are seeking discussion before proposing it.Another proposal involves enhancing OP_CHECKSEQUENCEVERIFY to allow outputs to be spendable by different parties at different times, but this also raises concerns about potential scams and unforeseen implications. Brandon Smith suggests other approaches like Lightning, improved fee estimation, and improved mempool eviction/re-propagation resistance to improve the ecosystem around delayed transactions and refunds. The usefulness of such studies in concluding on opportunities for future developments is emphasized.The bitcoin-dev mailing list is currently discussing a proposal for a new BIP that would extend OP_CSV and/or OP_CLTV to allow negative values. This will enable the ownership of coins to be shared between two parties for a certain period of time after which only one party owns them, without introducing reorg-induced invalidity. However, there are concerns about enforcing the 24-hour timelock, as it requires Bob to check the Blockchain in case he needs to publish a proof-of-fraud and add extra funds to the transaction to account for penalization.It was suggested that the more tenable ways to move forward on improving the ecosystem around delayed transactions and refunds are: Lightning, improved fee estimation, and improved mempool eviction/re-propagation resistance. The original reason for looking into this was because during high fee periods, transactions could re-propagate between mempools of differing policies resulting in coins being stuck unusable for far longer than the expected 1-2 week eviction. However, no concrete work is known to be going into investigating or improving this issue.Gregory Maxwell replied to the current conversation stating that although the proposed functionality has been suggested before, it has been deemed harmful. The existing design of CLTV/CSV was created to make it impossible for a transaction to go from valid to invalid based on time. This is because when a spend goes from valid to invalid, it means that a reorganization will destroy coins regardless of any dishonest actions of the coin's prior owner. Maxwell argues that non-monotone validity events in a coin's recent history function like a recently generated coin, which is a coin that reorgs destroy. Bitcoin addresses this issue with recently generated coins by not permitting their use for 100 blocks.The email was sent to the bitcoin-dev mailing list and can be viewed at https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/mailman/listinfo/bitcoin-dev. A similar functionality was proposed seven months ago, which can be found at https://github.com/reardencode/bips/blob/reverselocktime/bip-0zzz.mediawiki.
